_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary



1.    Facility Policy.  KAAPA Ethanol, L.L.C corporate policies place the utmost importance on worker, public, and environmental safety, which is reflected in facility plans and training activities.  The owners, management and employees of the KAAPA Ethanol facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of hazardous materials.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Kearney County Emergency Management (Local Emergency Planning Committee), and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment. The 5 year PHA that is required in March of 2020 has been pushed out until June, 2020 due to the CO-VID 19 virus and with all required updates anticipated due for completion by July 31,2020. 



2.    Facility Information. The primary activity at the facility is the processing of grain into fuel-grade ethyl alcohol.  The ethyl alcohol manufacturing process involves the use of anhydrous ammonia and natural gasoline.  The natural gasoline is referred to as product denaturant and is used to make the ethyl alcohol unfit for human consumption.   



3.    Five-Year Accident History.  No accidents have occurred within the most recent five-year period. 



4.    Emergency Response.  The emergency response program established by KAAPA Ethanol allows for personnel to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances in the event the release can be controlled using KAAPA Ethanol personnel and equipment in the area.  KAAPA Ethanol has identified additional resources to assist in mitigation, control and disposal of a release.  The local emergency response agencies will be relied upon to inform the public about the release. KAAPA Ethanol has developed an Emergency Action Plan outlining actions taken in the event of an accidental release of regulated substances as well as in the event of natural disasters.  The Emergency Action Plan

is provided below for reference.  



5.    KAAPA Ethanol has an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) in place to respond to prevent and respond to chemical spills on site. The details in the ERAP are provided after the Emergency Action Plan within this Executive Summary. 



6.    Accidental Release Prevention Program.   KAAPA Ethanol, L.L.C. plant has implemented several environmental, emergency, and safety programs at the facility.  These plans are crucial in our everyday operation and procedures.  Daily, weekly, and monthly checks are completed that affect our ability to respond to emergencies, including a Health and Safety Plan.   Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) and Storm Water Pollution Prevention (SWPP) plans have been prepared and implemented, with updates completed as needed to ensure compliance and effectiveness.   All implementation is accordance with the applicable regulatory standards and time frames.  KAAPA Ethanol has developed a Prevention Program in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 for a Program Level 3 facility.  The facility conducts weekly and monthly training as part of our normal activities.  Training consists of regulated safety requirements.  A Process Safety Management (PSM) program has been implemented in accordance to regulation.  Natural gasoline (denaturant) is a PSM-applicable chemical mixture on site.  The PSM program covers distillation tanks and piping, and storage tanks utilized for anhydrous ethanol and denatured ethyl alcohol.   Safety inspections are completed regularly, utilizing in-house and outside expertise to conduct.  Periodic reviews are completed on plans and procedures in place, with scheduling for additional training as part of the review process.  As previously mentioned in section 5 of this executive summary, KAAPA Ethanol implements an ERAP as part of the Spill Prevention Control & Countermeasure requirement to prevent and respond to chemical spills on site. In addition, KAAPA Ethano

l has a Facility Response Plan (FRP) to respond to chemical spills on site. Both the ERAP and the FRP are regulated under the Oil Pollution Prevention regulation.

A preventative system (Llumin CMMS system) is used by KAAPA Ethanol to confirm chemical storage tanks are in proper working condition.



7.    Planned changes to Improve Safety.  Safety improvements are an on-going process at KAAPA Ethanol.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions of the facility.  KAAPA Ethanol has a metal integrity written plan in place to confirm chemical storage tanks are in proper working condition. A preventative system (ER Portal) is also used by KAAPA Ethanol to confirm chemical storage tanks are in proper working condition.



EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN 



I)    Policy Statement: KAAPA Ethanol, LLC believes that its employees are its most important asset, and that their safety and health are among its greatest responsibilities.  

Therefore, this Emergency Action Plan has been established in compliance with the OSHA standard, Title 29 CFR 1910.38(a), and posted in various areas for employees.



II)    Purpose: This Emergency Action Plan is intended to ensure the proper response to foreseeable emergencies and where necessary, ensure the orderly evacuation of employees from work locations to a safe area away from conditions that could be immediately dangerous to life and health. 



III)    Responsibility and Authority

A)    The Program Coordinator  Tim Vogt has been assigned by the Chief Executive Officer to oversee:

  1)    The development, implementation and ongoing improvement of this Emergency Action Plan. 

  2)    Development and posting of the Emergency Action Plan and site exit diagram

  3)    All emergency equipment is inspected at various intervals to ensure proper operation of all emergency equipment.

  4)    Periodic drills of the emergency action plan.

B)    Visitors

  1)    The following procedure will be followed by all visitors/contractors entering the facility

   (a)    Mond

ay - Friday between 8:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. all visitor/contractors will sign in and out at the administrative office.  In the event work schedule starts or continues past normal office hours sign in 

        will be completed at control room check/sign in ledger 

   (b)    Monday - Friday between 4:30 p.m. - 7:30 a.m. all visitor/contractors will check/sign  in and out at the control room ledger

     (i)    Contractors on site are required to supply information as to company name and total number of personnel on site at all times

   (c)    Contractors, if not accompanied by a KAAPA employee may be given a radio to communicate critical or emergency situations in the event one arises.  This will be determined during project planning, pre-job 

        briefing, or heightened security risk.  

   (d)    If an evacuation is required, control room board operator will collect check /sign in ledger, located in control room as a means of identifying contractors on site.  Administrative office will collect 

        check in cards/ledger and gather at the safe gathering location.  A role call will occur, in the event someone is presumed to be missing, attempts will be made through radio communication.  If unsuccessful 

        wait for emergency services to arrive before reentering the facility.

C)    Incident Managers 

  1)    The following personnel have been assigned and trained to take charge in the event of an emergency, and depending on their availability at the time of the emergency, shall take charge in the following 

        order:  

   (a)    Day Shift (Monday - Friday)

     (i)    Tim Vogt - Environmental/Safety Manager

     (ii)    Tony Beam -Plant Manager

     (iii)    Troy Anderson- Production Manager

   (b)    Night Shift, Weekends & Holidays

     (i)    Brain Sinsel - Crew Chief

     (ii)    Kevin Betke  - Crew Chief

     (iii)    Tommy Jameson - Crew Chief

     (iv)    Glen Strickland - Crew Chief

  2)    Their responsibilities will include, but not be limited to:

   (a)    Ensuring all eme

rgency contacts has been made (emergency services, corporate, etc.).

   (b)    Ensuring all personnel has been safely evacuated by the Evacuation Wardens.

   (c)    Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.

   (d)    Overall responsibility for the management of the emergency.



D)    Evacuation Wardens 

  1)    The following personnel have been assigned and trained to ensure, in any potential event or emergency that they're assigned areas are completely evacuated of employees, visitors and contractors during an 

        actual emergency situation or mock drill.

   (a)    Administrative Building

     (i)    Day Shift

       (1)    Kristi Carlson 

       (2)    Tony Beam

   (b)    Maintenance / Contractors 

     (i)    Day Shift

       (1)    Dan Mainwaring 

     (ii)    Night Shift, Weekends, & Holidays 

     (iii)    Brian Sinsel - Crew Chief

     (iv)    Kevin Betke - Crew Chief

     (v)    Tommy Jameson - Crew Chief

     (vi)    Glen Strickland - Crew Chief

     (vii)    Randy Job - Rover

     (viii)    Jason Holsten - Rover  

   (c)    Grain Delivery Drivers/Alcohol Drivers/Denaturant Drivers

     (i)    Day Shift

       (1)    Brad Carlson / Kenneth Wright  - Yard Man

   (d)    Wet Cake drivers

     (i)    Day Shift/Night Shift

       (1)    Shawn Smith  - Wet Cake Load Out

       (2)    Dusty Galusha - Wet Cake Load Out

       (3)    Lathan Thompson- Wet Cake Load Out

       (4)    Dylon Baxter   - Wet Cake Load Out

  2)    Each Evacuation Warden will report to the Incident Manager at the gathering location.

  3)    Medical Emergency and First Aid Providers - All personnel have been trained to provide first aid treatment while awaiting emergency medical treatment.

E)    Trainer:  Tim Vogt, Environmental Safety Manager has been assigned to train personnel in the Emergency Action Plan, as follows:

  1)    Current and New Employees shall know and understand:

    (a)    The emergency situations anticipated in the plan.

    (b)    How they will be notified of an emergency situation.

    (c)    How and whe

n they should initiate the emergency action plan.

    (d)    Where to gather or take shelter in the event of an emergency situation.

    (e)    How and when to use a fire extinguisher (Incipient stage only).

    (f)    Types of Emergencies

  2)    Those with specific responsibilities within the plan shall be trained according to their responsibilities, including those with critical operation responsibility.

  3)    All personnel shall be re-trained anytime there is a change in the plan.

  4)    For hazardous material releases, 

  5)    The trainer shall maintain documentation of this training.

IV)    Potential Emergencies and Notification (alarm) Procedures 

A)    Fire - In the event of a small fire, the closest employee will notify management and attempt to extinguish it himself/herself.  If a fire is felt to have the potential to be beyond the employee's control, 

        they will shut down their equipment, activate the fire alarm system, (which is an intermittently alarm) and evacuate to the designated assembly point.  The Incident Manager on shift or the plant manager 

        will ensure that the fire department is met at in front of the administrative office and directed to the site of the fire.

B)    Tornado - A weather alert radio is located in the control room area where the control board operator can hear if a Tornado watch or warning is being issued.  Once a watch is issued the control board 

        operator needs to notify everyone via radio that we are in a Tornado watch.  If a Tornado warning is issued we are to notify personnel via radio, the incident manager and the crew chief monitor activities 

        through a 2-way radio on channel 3 in the control room, listening to the local spotters.  

C)    Hazardous Material Release - If a release is discovered notify Tim Vogt, the Environmental/Safety Manager, with additional notification to on shift incident managers.  

D)    Medical Emergency -



Normal Business Hours

    (a)    Plant Emergency Control Room / Crew Chief, w

ill call 911.  

    (b)    Administrative Building Emergency Chelsey Oltman or Tony Beam will call 911 in the event the emergency is at or in the vicinity of the administrative building.   

    (c)    Notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager 

    (d)    Jena Johnson or Tim Vogt, will notify the employee's emergency contact

  2)    Weekends, Holidays, & Nights

    (a)    Crew Chief will call 911

    (b)    Crew Chief will notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager immediately after calling 911

    (c)    If unable to contact Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager notify Troy Anderson, Production Manager

    (d)    Crew Chief will notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Troy Anderson, Production Manager of the Hospital and ambulance that is transporting the employee.

    (e)    Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Troy Anderson, Production Manager will notify the employee's emergency contact

    (f)    Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Troy Anderson, Production Manager will ensure that the company drug testing policy will be adhered to if drug testing is required.



V)    Emergency Contact Phone Numbers

A)    Fire - 911

B)    Emergency Medical - 911

C)    County Sheriff - 308-832-2805

D)         Hazardous Material Release - CHEM-TREC - 1-800-424-9300 



Managers             

Tim Vogt - Environmental/Safety Manager - 308-293-2991                        

Troy Anderson - Production Manager - 308-455-0195  

Tony Beam - Plant  Manager - 308-293-2448

                          Robert Williams - Maintenance ager - 308-440-8801 





Definitions:

Term    Definition

Plant Emergency    Any undesired event that could lead to the personal injury of employees, contractors, or visitors, or the damage to KAAPA Ethanol, LLC property.

Active Shooter    An individual who is engaged in killing or attempting to kill people in a confined and populated area; in most cases, active shooters use firearms and there is no pattern or method to their selection of victims.

Gas Shut Off or Signif

icant Change in Gas Flow    Means that if a plant upset, or any abnormal disturbance to natural gas flow to the facility is made, either planned or as part of an emergency shutdown. See Energy Maintenance Services provisions.

Severe Weather Watch    Means that conditions are favorable for development of a severe storm.  This may include such things as high winds, heavy rain, hail and/or lightning.  The winter version, Severe Winter Storm Warning, could also produce heavy snow, and hazardous sub-zero wind chills.

Severe Weather Warning    Indicates that a dangerous storm is imminent.  Note:  A severe weather warning is not necessarily a prerequisite step for a tornado warning.  When conditions are favorable for severe weather, they may also be favorable for a tornado.  It is possible for a severe weather warning and tornado conditions to be present at the same time.

Tornado Watch    Issued by the National Weather Service, indicates the weather conditions are adequate for the development of a tornado. A watch condition could exist for up to 12 hours.

Tornado Warning    Means a tornado or funnel cloud has been sighted in the area, or is indicated on radar.  Tornado warning status means there is immediate danger of tornado(s), and that tornado emergency procedures should be initiated.

    

VI)    Emergency Gathering and Shelter Locations

A)    Fire or Hazardous Material Release - In the event of an evacuation the primary meeting location will be in the North East edge of the administration building parking lot.  

B)    Tornado - In the event of a tornado warning all plant personnel are to take shelter in the grain pits, restrooms, or shelter in maintenance building.  Administrative personnel are to take shelter in the basement restrooms of the administrative office building.  Contractor's and all drivers onsite during a tornado warning will be required to take shelter in the grain receiving pit or restroom areas.   

VII)    Emergency Equipment Location List 

A)    Fire extinguishers are locat

ed throughout the entire facility 

B)    Fire hydrants are located throughout the facility along access roads. 

C)    Fire hydrant guns located in the Ethanol truck/rail load out & around the tank farm

D)    First aid kits are located

  1)    Administrative Office (next to stairs) 

  2)    In Process Building Break Room



VIII)     The Program Coordinator will:

A)    Coordinate annuals drills for potential emergency anticipated.  

B)    Initiate the drill in the same manner as an actual event.

C)    Pre-notify the following personnel to ensure no conflicts with important meetings or VIP visits.

  1)    Chuck Woodside - Chief Executive Officer 

  2)    Tony Beam - Plant Manager

  3)    Troy Anderson - Production Manager

  4)    Robert Willaims  - Maintenance Manager

D)    Schedule the drills as follows:

  1)    Fire Drills - When possible time permitting year around, table top events.  

  2)    Tornado Drills - In early spring, when Severe Weather is at its greatest opportunity 

  3)    Hazardous Material Spills - Table top events or mock drills at time determined to be least disruptive to production. 

E)    A post-drill review will be completed by the Environmental Safety Manager, discussing with Managers and Employees, any needed improvements in the plan. 

F)    Make necessary changes to the plan, and re-train those affected by the changes. 

G)    An actual event may suffice as one of the scheduled annual drills, as long as there is a meeting with the Incident Managers and Employees to discuss any needed improvements in the plan.  



IX)    Posting - The Program Coordinator will have available copies of programs in critical areas of facility:

A)    The Emergency Action Plan Routes of Evacuation (exit doors)

B)    The Diagram of the plant or worksite, and surrounding area showing:

  1)    Routes of exit

  2)    Primary Evacuation locations



X)    Action Plans for Potential Emergencies:

A)    Fire Evacuation Procedures 

  1)    If a fire is discovered in its incipient (initial, early) stage: 

   (a)    Immediately notify C

rew Chief 

   (b)    Extinguish the fire with the provided equipment (one extinguisher or pull suppression system if available; and

   (c)    Immediately inform an Incident Manager (environmental safety manager) of the incident.

  2)    If the fire has spread, or appears too big for ONE extinguisher to handle, or the area is thick with smoke:

   (a)    Sound the alarm activating the fire alarm system

   (b)    Notify Crew Chief, Call emergency services 911 

   (c)    Determine if Evacuation is Needed, Evacuate to the Parking Lot on the North East Side of the Administrative Building 

   (d)    At the Parking Lot on the North East Side of the Administrative Building inform the Incident Manager exactly why you called for the evacuation and whether emergency services were contacts.

  3)    All employees will, upon hearing the alarm, evacuate to the Parking Lot on the  North East Side of the Administrative Building (see diagram)

  4)    Evacuation Wardens will, upon hearing the alarm:

   (a)    Ensure their areas are evacuated, telling people along the way where to gather.

   (b)    Report to the Incident Manager at the Parking Lot on the East Side of the Administrative Building.

  5)    The Incident Manager will:

   (a)    Ensure emergency services are contacted.

   (b)    If Natural Gas to the plant needs to be shut off, Identify and designate an employee to close either the valve behind the Energy Center or our main station behind the Cooling Tower.

   (c)    Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.

   (d)    Notify the Environmental Health & Safety Manager.

   (e)    Account for Personnel

  6)    The Incident Manager will:

   (a)    Announce the all clear, or

   (b)    Determine when it is safe to return to work.

B)    Tornado Procedures 

  1)    During a Tornado warning, personnel will be informed of the hazard via radio.  

  2)    Employees will take shelter in Grain Silo Pits, Break Room Restroom, Records Room in Maintenance building, or Basement Restrooms of Administrative Build

ing, 

  3)    The Evacuation Wardens will, upon hearing the notification, ensure their areas are evacuated, telling people along the way where to take shelter.

  4)    If time does not permit taking shelter in the designated areas, employees should:

   (a)    Gather in the lowest, center-most area possible.  (Avoid areas with large span roofs.)

   (b)    Move away from windows and exterior walls.

   (c)    Get under heavy machines, desks, tables, or other sturdy objects.  

   (d)    Remember the objective is to avoid being struck by flying debris.  

  5)    The Incident Manager will:

   (a)    Announce the all clear, or

   (b)    If there is any structural damage to the building, will have the Evacuation Wardens evacuate people to the Parking Lot on the North East Side of the Administrative Building. 

      (i) The 2-way radio on channel 3in control room can inform the emergency services of an injury or fire located on site (This radio is to be used to communicate with emergency services for emergencies 

        ONLY)

   (c)    Determine when it is safe to return to work.

      (i)    The local emergency services will notify KAAPA employees when it is safe to return to work.

C)    Hazardous Material Release Procedure 

  1)    Contact Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager  Incident Manager or additional Incident Manager if any of the following materials are released: 

   (a)    Natural Gasoline (Denaturant) - Tank Farm on West Side of Plant

   (b)    DCI-11 - Tank Farm on West Side of Plant

   (c)    200 Proof Alcohol - Storage in Tank Farm on West Side of Plant/Distillation Area

   (d)    190 Proof Alcohol - Storage in Tank Farm on West Side of Plant/Distillation Area

   (e)    Caustic Soda - Storage in Process Building

   (f)    Sulfuric Acid - Storage outside of North Door of Process Building

   (g)    Diesel - Tank in Fire Water Building & Behind Process Building

   (h)    Natural Gas - Fenced in area South of Tank Farm, and throughout the facility.  If there is a fire or release involving Natural Gas

, and it is safe, the employee can shut off the Natural Gas on the West 

        Side of the Energy Center or at the Station South of the Tank Farm

   (i)    Denatured Ethanol - Storage in Tank Farm West Side of Plant/Distillation Area



  2)    Evacuate people from immediate area, if necessary. 

  3)    The Incident Managers will:

   (a)    Evaluate the hazards of a release to determine the following:

     (i)    If the release can be safely handled by those working in the area with equipment normally available in the area, or 

     (ii)    If the release constitutes an emergency, where upon s/he shall 

        (1)    Call upon the Evacuation Wardens to evacuate the general area.

        (2)    Attempt to stop and begin to contain the release, if safe to do so. 

        (3)    Organize the Hazardous Materials team to contain and clean up the release (Safety Kleen).

        (4)    Contact Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager, who will contact the proper governmental agency, if necessary.

   (b)    Determine when it is safe to return to normal duty in the areas.

D)    Emergency Medical or First-aid Procedure

1)    All personnel have been trained to provide emergency first aid and CPR when summoned to do so in an emergency.  

2)    These personnel will provide critical first aid treatment while waiting on paramedics to arrive.

3)    If someone is in need of emergency medical or first aid attention, 

   (a)    Normal Business Hours

     (i)    Kristie Carlson / Tony Beam will call 911 for front administration, Crew chiefs for Operation areas, Maintenance lead for  maintenance   

     (ii)    Roles & Responsibilities

        (1)    Make employee comfortable while he/she waits for the ambulance

        (2)    Do not move employee unless he/she is in immediate danger

        (3)    Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.

        (4)    Identify what medical facility the injured employee is being transported to.

        (5)    Scott Olson or Tim Vogt, will notify the employee's emerge

ncy contact

   (b)     Weekends, Holidays, & Nights

     (i)    Crew Chief will call 911

     (ii)    Crew Chief will notify Safety Manager immediately after calling 911

     (iii)    If unable to contact the Safety Manager notify the Plant  Manager

     (iv)    Roles & Responsibilities

        (1)    Make employee comfortable while he/she waits for ambulance

        (2)    Do not move employee unless he/she is in immediate danger

        (3)    Communicate and coordinate with emergency services upon their arrival.

        (4)    Identify what medical facility the injured employee is being transported to.

        (5)    Crew Chief will notify Tim Vogt, Environmental/Safety Manager or Tony Beam, Plant Manager of the Medical Facility the ambulance is transporting the employee to.

        (6)    Tim Vogt, Environmental Safety Manager or Tony Beam, Plant Manager will notify the employee's emergency contact



E)    Active Shooter Event:



Active shooter Procedures and how to respond when an active shooter is in your vicinity, determine the most reasonable way to protect your own life. Remember that customers and                                                 clients are likely to follow the lead of employees and managers during an active shooter situation. 

  a) RUN 

     If there is an accessible escape path, attempt to evacuate the premises. Be sure to: 

                                               ? Have an escape route and plan in mind 

                                               ? Evacuate regardless of whether others agree to follow 

                                               ? Leave your belongings behind 

                                               ? Help others escape, if possible 

                                               ? Prevent individuals from entering an area where the active shooter may be 

                                               ? Keep your hands visible 

                                               ? Follow the instructions of any police o

fficers 

                                               ? Do not attempt to move wounded people 

                                               ? Call 911 when you are safe 



  b) HIDE 

      If evacuation is not possible, find a place to hide where the active shooter is less likely to find you. 



                                           Your hiding place should: 

                                              ? Be out of the active shooter's view 

                                              ? Provide protection if shots are fired in your direction (i.e., an office with a closed and locked door) 

                                              ? Not trap you or restrict your options for movement 



                                           To prevent an active shooter from entering your hiding place: 

                                              ? Lock the door 

                                              ? Blockade the door with heavy furniture 



                                           If the active shooter is nearby: 

                                             ? Lock the door 

                                             ? Silence your cell phone and/or pager 

                                             ? Turn off any source of noise (i.e., radios, televisions) 

                                             ? Hide behind large items (i.e., cabinets, desks) 

                                             ? Remain quiet 



                                          If evacuation and hiding out are not possible: 

                                             ? Remain calm 

                                             ? Dial 911, if possible, to alert police to the active shooter's location 

                                             ? If you cannot speak, leave the line open and allow the dispatcher to listen 



  c) FIGHT 

                                          As a last resort, and only when your life is in imminent danger, atte

mpt to disrupt and/or incapacitate the active shooter by: 



                                          ? Acting as aggressively as possible against him/her 

                                          ? Throwing items and improvising weapons 

                                          ? Yelling 

                                          ? Committing to your actions
